title: Top judge says families of Essex lorry death victims should be granted UK visa
text:
Former judge calls on government to take a more humanitarian approach to migrants in the wake of the Essex lorry tragedy (Picture: PA/EPA)

A retired judge has called on the UK government to allow families of the Essex lorry victims into the country to help with the investigation.

Catriona Jarvis, a former immigration judge, said relatives should be fully involved in inquests into the deaths of their loved ones.

The bodies of eight women and 31 men were found in a refrigeration trailer at an industrial park in Grays, Essex, On Wednesday October 23.

It is believed a number of the people were from Vietnam, despite Essex Police initially saying they were all Chinese nationals.

Ms Jarvis welcomed efforts from the National Crime Agency to identify the victims but said bereaved families should be given more support to help with the process.

She said: ‘We should be working with the families, not putting obstacles in their way.

Ms Jarvis criticised the response of the home secretary, Priti Patel, who said she would consider stronger penalties against smugglers (Picture: Rex Features)

‘They should be issued with visas to come to the UK and they should have access to legal advice.

‘We are calling for support to be put in place for families once everyone in the lorry has been identified so they can participate fully in the investigations.’

Ms Jarvis is co-convenor of the Last Rights project, which works to protect the rights of missing and dead migrants and their grieving families.

She criticised Home Secretary Priti Patel’s response to the tragedy, saying it was ‘woefully insufficient’ to suggest stronger penalties against people smugglers would prevent future tragedies.

She told the Guardian: ‘I don’t think Priti Patel’s approach is realistic. We need to look at the reasons why people are moving as well as at exploitation by smugglers or traffickers. We need to look at both at the same time.’

People hold a candlelight vigil for the victims that died in the lorry container (Picture: EPA)

Jarvis advocated mechanisms which would allow migrants to make the journey to the UK safer, such as humanitarian visas.

The human rights campaigner was instrumental in drawing up the landmark Mytilini Declaration document, which established rights and duties towards families of migrants who have gone missing or died.

‘We are working to create a more respectful legal framework for the rights of dead migrants’ she said.

‘We need to look at things through the eyes of the bereaved.’
